questions.text: The majority of cases of diabetes can be broadly classified into 2 categories: type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes, although some cases are difficult to classify. Gestational diabetes (GDM) refers to glucose intolerance with onset or first recognition during pregnancy. What is the recent major basis of the classification of DM into types 1 and 2?
questions.correct_answer: C. Pathogenic process leading to hyperglycemia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pathogenic process leading to hyperglycemia DM is classified on the basis of the pathogenic process leading to hyperglycemia , as opposed to earlier criteria such as the age of onset or type of therapy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. used in earlier classification. Age or treatment modality is not a criterion. Although type 1 DM most commonly develops before the age of 30, autoimmunity against beta cells can develop at any age. It is estimated that between 5 and 10% of individuals who develop DM after age 30 have type 1 dm. Although type 2 DM more typically develops with increasing age, it is now being diagnosed more frequently in children and young adults, particularly in obese adolescents. Option: B. it was used in earlier classification. The terms insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (IDDM) or non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) are no longer used. Because many individuals with type 2 DM eventually require insulin treatment for control of glycemia, the use of the term NIDDM generated considerable confusion. Option: D. not the basis.

For all individuals aged >45 years, screening for DM is repeated every 3 years The ADA recommends screening all individuals aged >45 years every 3 years and screening individuals at an earlier age if they are overweight (BMI> 25 kg/m2 or ethnically relevant definition for overweight) and have one additional risk factor for diabetes.

questions.text: Shyam 45-year-old diabetic man presented with abdominal pain, and grey pigmentation on his face, neck and dorsum of hands. On examination, you found hepatomegaly and conducted investigations which pointed out towards increased transferrin saturation of 58%. The best mode of treatment, in this case, is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phlebotomy The patient in question has hemochromatosis as evidenced by the findings The therapy of hemochromatosis involves the removal of excess body iron and supportive treatment of damaged organs. Iron removal is best accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 ml. One 500ml unit of blood removes 200-250 mg of iron. Therefore, in patients with advanced disease, weekly phlebotomy may be required for 1–2 years, and it should be continued until the serum ferritin level is ≤ 100 μg/l. Thereafter, phlebotomies are performed at appropriate intervals to maintain ferritin levels at ≤ 100 μg/l. Thereafter one phlebotomy is sufficient every 3 months It is less expensive, more convenient and safe

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. I.V.Deferoxamine v. Chelating agents like deferoxamine only remove 10-20mg iron/day which is very less compared to phlebotomy Option C - Deferasirox An oral chelating agent is still under clinical trial though available as Exjade Effective in thalassemia and secondary iron overload Option D - Reduce intake of iron-rich foods Intake of vitamin C should be avoided as it increases iron absorption Iron supplements should be avoided

questions.text: Which of the following insulin can be mixed with other insulin?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NPH The following guidelines should be followed while mixing insulins: mix the different insulin formulations in the syringe immediately before injection (inject within 2 min after mixing); do not store insulin as a mixture; follow the same routine in terms of insulin mixing and administration to standardize the physiologic response to injected insulin ; and do not mix insulin glargine, detemir, or degludec with other insulins. The miscibility of some insulins allows for the production of combination insulins that contain 70% NPH and 30% regular (70/30), or equal mixtures of NPH and regular (50/50). By including the insulin analogue mixed with protamine, several additional combinations have a short-acting and long-acting profile

Solution:

Thickening of basement membranes, mesangial expansion and a Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodule Nodular diabetic glomerulosclerosis: Pathologically, the first changes coincide with the onset of microalbuminuria and include the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and the accumulation of matrix material in the mesangium. Subsequently, nodular deposits are characteristic, and glomerulosclerosis worsens as heavy proteinuria develops until glomeruli are progressively lost and renal function deteriorates. There is the thickening of basement membranes, mesangial expansion and a Kimmelstiel–Wilson nodule (arrow), which is pathognomonic of diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly involved in Nerve compression palsies in diabetic neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Median nerve Mononeuropathies are severe and of rapid onset, but they eventually recover. The nerves most commonly affected are the 3rd and 6th cranial nerves (resulting in diplopia), and the femoral and sciatic nerves. Rarely, involvement of other single nerves results in paresis and paraesthesiae in the thorax and trunk (truncal radiculopathies).

Highyeild:

Nerve compression palsies are more common in diabetes, frequently affecting the median nerve and giving the clinical picture of carpal tunnel syndrome, and less commonly the ulnar nerve. Lateral popliteal nerve compression occasionally causes foot drop. Compression palsies may be more common because of glycosylation and thickening of connective tissue and/or because of increased susceptibility of nerves affected by diabetic microangiopathy. Nerve compression palsies are more common in diabetes, frequently affecting the median nerve and giving the clinical picture of carpal tunnel syndrome, and less commonly the ulnar nerve.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Less commonly the ulnar nerve. Option: C. Lateral popliteal nerve compression occasionally causes foot drop. Option: D. Rare .

questions.text: An arthropathy is characterized by early inflammation and then joint dislocation, subluxation and pathological fractures of the foot of neuropathic patients, often resulting in debilitating deformity. The X-ray is shown below. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetes mellitus Charcot neuroarthropathy can arise in any condition that causes neuropathy (including syphilis, spinal cord injury, syringomyelia etc.) but diabetes is the most common cause.

Highyeild:

Acute Charcot neuroarthropathy almost always presents with signs of inflammation – a hot, red, swollen foot. The initial x-ray may show bony destruction but is often normal. As about 40%of patients with a Charcot's joint also have a foot ulcer, it can be difficult to differentiate it from osteomyelitis. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the foot is often helpful. The mainstay of treatment or an active Charcot foot is immobilisation and, ideally avoidance of weight-bearing on the affected foot. The rationale is that if no pressure is applied through the foot, the destructive process involving bones results in significant deformity when the acute inflammatory process subsides.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B, & D. Less common cause.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was recently diagnosed as having acromegaly. Which of the following indicates acromegaly 1. Impaired glucose tolerance 2. Galactorrhea 3. Hypertension 4. Suppression of GH with glucose 5. Low serum phosphate Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1,2,3 Impaired glucose tolerance, galactorrhea and hypertension are seen in patients with acromegaly Statement 4: suppression of GH with glucose Physiological GH secretion is inhibited by hyperglycemia as GH is a part of the counter-regulatory defence mechanism against hypoglycemia. Statement 5: low serum phosphate Growth hormone leads to an increase in the reabsorption of phosphate and hence increases serum phosphate levels

questions.text: The patient, 52 years old, is an obese patient. The patient is having glut 4 defects. The patient does not have any symptoms. It is found that the patient is having hyperinsulinemia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type 2 diabetes mellitus In the question, the patient is given to be an adult patient who is obese The presence of glut 4 defect gives us an idea of type two diabetes mellitus Normally glut 4 defect moves from cytosol to cell membrane to attach to glucose and bring the glucose into the cell But here the defect will lead to improper absorption of glucose So in the early stages of the disease due to relative deficiency of glucose, there is paradoxical hyperinsulinemia. Hence there is initial hyperinsulinemia This should not be confused with the diagnosis of hypoglycaemia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. hypoglycaemia Here the patient is having a glut 4 defect, in which there are early stages of hyperinsulinemia This is because normally the glut 4 defect helps in the movement of glucose from the cytosol to the cell membrane But due to the defect, there is so inadequate absorption of glucose Because of this deficiency, there is hyperinsulinemia This is a diagnosis of type tw o diabetes mellitus and thus this excludes the options of hypoglycaemia in which there is no variation of hyperinsulinemia in the early stage and eventual correction Option: C. latent diabetes When a person becomes diabetic under stressful conditions like pregnancy, and the patient becomes normal when the stressful condition is removed, this is called latent diabetes. Hence this option is excluded as there is no mention of stressful conditions Option: D. brittle diabetes Brittle diabetes is seen in children with type one diabetes The children have a wide fluctuation in the their blood sugar level Sometimes patients sugar becomes very high leading to diabetic ketoacidosis or the patient also can go into a coma Hence this option is excluded because glut 4 defect is characteristic of type 2 diabetes mellitus and the patient is also an adult
